abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, and the institutional development
            impact as substantial. However, lessons indicate that when
            the project was extended, foreseeing that the capacity of
            the Malawi Rural Finance Company (MRFC) was not attainable
            as a private bank, the project should have instead been
            restructured, in line with current conditions, and allow for
            an opportunity to assist the Government in pursuing improved
            policy, and institutional frameworks. Furthermore, since the
            issue of rural finance, in an agriculturally-based economy
            as Malawi's is a highly political one, efforts to
            strengthen relations among the Government, its agencies,
            donors ant the private sector at large, need to be pursued,
            since MRFC activities were seen only as a Bank project. This
            would in turn enable macroeconomic stability, and develop
            commercial financial institutions, viable to financial
            services, that include both savings, and credit facilities
            to the rural population. But the capacity of rural financial
            institutions needs to be revisited, focusing on issues of
            loan recovery mechanisms, efficient marketing systems,
            subsidy elements, and furthermore, financial institutions
            lending for agricultural purposes, need to create reserves
            for default, resulting from the risks of macroeconomic
            instability. Licensing these institutions under the
            country's banking legislation, would enable supervision accordingly.
